description:
Discovered this while I was in SF. Their vanilla latte is very similar to a coffee shop in LA called, "Commissary", which I LOVE.

Definitely will be back next time I'm in town.
author: Emily X.

description:
Randomly walked in to get something to drink and discovered Equator Coffees and Teas.  It is a nice coffee shop to sit and watch the people go by on Market.  They offer indoor and outdoor seating which gives you options while you sip your coffee and people watch.  There is also free wifi if you want to have a place to get a little work done.

Since it was a beautiful and "warm" day for San Francisco, we skipped the coffee and decided to get some iced teas. We ordered the iced black tea and the iced rooibos chai latte. The black tea was refreshing and the chai latte was creamy and full of spices.  The service was friendly and helpful when it came to deciding what to order.  Next time I will have to try the coffee.
author: Michelle D.

description:
Nice place to sit in a bad part of Market St.  

Given the high quality of their beans the cappuccino is amazingly meh....

Underextracted, watery. 
I guess their machine is hard to use to get it right.  

Otherwise fine.
author: Flo B.

description:
Great little coffee spot on Market in the Tenderloin, right next to The Warfield. There's some seating on the inside plus a few tables outside, and free wifi if you need to get a little work done. 

Their iced latte with oat milk is solid. 16oz for $5, so it's about on par with city pricing. 

I stopped by for about an hour and a half earlier today, slowly sipping my drink while slapping away at the keyboard. Can't remember if they were playing music or not, as the doors were open to the noise from outside. I actually enjoyed that and was able to get some quality work done.
author: Jon S.

description: Stopped by to get a Shakerato. Small 8 oz cup of 2 shots espresso (I asked for 1, because I want to sleep tonight), cream, and some brown sugar. I got the Scratch Caramel, asked for light sweetener. Didn't really taste any caramel, but tastes strong, rich, aromatic, and creamy. A great midday pick me up. However, it's HELLA EXPENSIVE. $3.75 for a couple sips of espresso......
author: Hanna M.

description: Great affogato. Nice, shaded outdoor seating available. Very clean interior and restrooms. Friendly staff.
author: Scott Z.

description: Service has notably Improved since they first opened. It's still confusing to figure out where to order and pick up your drinks. But it's nice to have an upscale coffee place on this part of Market Street.
author: Tim P.

description:
Quick, easy and out the door. 

Stopped by to grab a cold brew. Friendly staff and drinks made pretty quickly. Cold brew was perfect, strong enough to last me the whole day! Decently priced as well. 

I have yet to try other items off them menu. I'll be back!
author: Elaine C.

description: Boo! I have afew friends who have worked here so I keep trying it...its never any better. If you are a coffee snob dont go here. If gas station coffee and sour coffee are good to you then by all means. Staff is nice but not knowledgeable about coffee at all
author: Amber A.

description: Ordered a large vanilla latte with oat milk; 2 words: ON POINT! It was sweeter than I normally drink coffee, all because i forgot to ask for little sugar, but it was soooooooooo good! Highly recommended.
author: Hanh N.

description: Been here a few times and am addicted to their lattes. Everyone is friendly here and the service is pretty quick. Decent prices too!
author: J. M.

description: I love Equator! The CEO is so inspiring with such a great mission as well. The coffee is unbeatable!!
author: Katie B.

description: If you haven't had Equator's shakerato, you haven't experienced life. Shakerato: espresso, cream, a little sugar (I think?) and ice, shaken till nice and cold and frothy. Seriously, pop in for one of these and you will be SO happy that you did. It's the perfect pick-me-up. It cheers me up whenever I have time to drop in for one :)
author: Liz M.

description: I literally downloaded the yelp app just to tell you how nasty this chai tea latte is. It tastes like a flower pot--it literally has flowery notes and a dirt-like texture. It might be cinnamon + other spices, but they all float down and collect at the bottom of the drink; it's gritty and gross. Also, it's awfully overpriced for this not-that-good drink. It's a bunch of hippie hipster stuff so if you're into that and the taste of a flower bed, this is perfect for you. Me? Not so much.
author: Yula D.

description:
My girl and I were walking by and decided to grab a coffee before heading to breakfast. We were grabbing breakfast in Chinatown, so we thought Equator would be a good middle ground for us so we don't get too cranky/hangry on each other.

The employees upon entering let us know that they had excellent coffee. We asked for suggestions and they told us everything was essentially good. So we both went with iced almond milk lattes, one with vanilla and one with no flavor.

Prices were reasonable for coffee. But since we didn't like ours, it wasn't so reasonable.

The lattes were alright. Nothing amazing. They had a super oatmeal-y taste which my girlfriend seemed to like about it. But otherwise, we both agreed it was mediocre coffee.

Cool vibe and atmosphere.

Service was good.

Wouldn't come back though. Much better coffee places in SF.
author: Natasha S.

description:
I seriously don't know what I would do without Equator. Fantastic roasts, well made coffee (and cold brews that seriously DO IT for me) and a bunch of pastries (kouign amanns just MAKE MY MORNING) are a game changer at the edge of the Tenderloin/Powell area. A little pricey, but easily my go-to for before-work and during-work pick me ups.

If you're buying beans, I'd highly recommend the Guatemala Santa Sofia - I'm generally a dark roast kind of person, and this is the perfect medium roast for me.
author: Colleen M.

description:
i got a cherry rooibos soda (which it appears no one ever gets, oops). it was refreshing and tart and not that sweet, and so perfect for a post-work pick me up (though maybe not the best for a pre-movie afternoon, unless you want to squirm throughout the last half of "spiderman"). there's bits of cherries at the bottom, and it's the perfect amount of effervescence for me. if you like things super bubbly, this might not be for you. it's more of a cherry lemon soda than a cherry rooibos soda, but still tasty.

there's a bunch of different tables and that shaken espresso sounds pretty great, so i'll definitely be back.
author: Heather F.

description: Very cute store with free water offered for u to drink if u want to. Delicious espresso in cute tiny cup. Situated on busy market street for convenient coffee stop.
author: M C.

description:
Great patio for people watching 
The espresso and ice cream drink
Is a worthwhile visit , located next
To The Warfield and CrazyHorseSF 
Caffeine Destination Found
author: myron w.

description: I told the barista the style coffee i like and am delighted with what they selected - the breakfast sandwich +procuitto is fantastic and worth coming back for
author: Kristina C.

description:
One word: Shakerato

Espresso and cream. Shaken. Delish. Small serving, but it's what you get when you order an espresso. This drink is delightful if you're a coffee lover. It's creamy and caffeinated. Served cold.
author: Sharon B.

description: I've been here a couple of times and the coffee is horrible. Chai tea so sweet that you can't even taste the spices. Coffee very bitter and doesn't have any undertones to it. Overall not worth the high prices that are listed. Don't waste your time here.
author: Olivia C.

description:
Over the last few months, I've gotten to know a few folks working at Equator and one time they invited me over for a meeting to this location...and they dished out a lovely selection of their foods and coffee drinks. I love being pampered. 

Earlier this week I came back and met up with a friend for breakfast here. He was here from Germany and he stayed at one of the infamous hotels lining Mid-Market and so I suggested Equator, recalling their terrific frittata sandwich. (I like the one with chorizo, which is nice'n'spicy.) 

Granted, the location is less optimal for some as it is smack in the middle of everything that many people dislike about San Francisco: drug addicts & homeless people. What I learned from the Equator folks though - and that is one of the reasons I came back - is that they recruit from within this community. I like coming to the Tenderloin, as it kind of makes me aware that not all is well in that a little bubble we call San Francisco...

My only pet peeve is this: I've been here three times now and every time I walked in, I didn't get greeted...and it wasn't even super busy, as the staff were chatting with each other. This non-acknowledged entrance is enhanced by the fact that it's not super clear at which part of the counter to place your order. So for the first few moments I'm always a bit lost. But then, when I actually start having an interaction with the staff, they turn out to be super friendly and helpful.
author: Uli B.

description:
Right after work, I walked right by making my way to meet someone. When I glanced in, I saw it was a quaint little coffee shop so I walked in. 

This was a quick stop and what I bought was more of a treat for him than for me. I ordered a 12oz Scratch Caramel Latte which the barista told me was simply a latte made with housemade caramel. It was very much a good quality latte, latte art and all. I'm also glad that it wasn't too sweet -- the focus is on the coffee!

I have gone back twice since then. I went again and bought another coffee gift: 16oz vanilla latte. I didn't get to try this one, but I'm told that this was also great and more suited for his taste. The third time, I ordered a Cortado which is was like a cappuccino but with less milk/cream. Smooth and bitter, not very sweet. The favorite was the vanilla latte!

Glad to have walked into a great coffee shop! I'll be trying the teas and milk teas very soon in my future.
author: Sofia R.

description:
Love love love their coffee. The first time I had equator coffee was at the Ucsf  mission bay campus. From my first sip, I was hooked. I love how the baristas here always make my soy lattes with a heart or two... it really makes me feel special. 

Their coffee is always consistent... not overpowering but just right. The lady helping us was really nice and a man outside needed water and she was really sweet in giving him what he needed. I was skeptical about the change going on in this neighborhood but when you have people who are willing to just be nice people to others despite any kind of differences, it's definitely a good change. 

My husband and I ordered a plain and almond croissant as well and they were so delicious! A really good croissant + the best coffee = happy me... lol.
author: Reese E.

description:
Checked in on 5/31/2016.

I did not try the coffee, but I took one of the granola bars which they make and sell.  It was excellent.  I kept wondering next day, why I did not buy few more.  Well, there's always a next time.
author: Anjali A.

description:
Decided to come here to grab some coffee and catch up with a friend, and it did not disappoint! I got the caramel latte with soy and she got the vanilla latte. It was yummy, not too sweet. We also ordered the vegetarian quiche to share (it was a nice decent size!) and OMG. It was so good. So much flavor and amazing texture. Also came with a little mixed green side salad. I recommend coming here for even just the quiche alone!! 
The staff was also very sweet and welcoming, which is a big deal for me. Customer service is everything.
author: Tiffany S.

description: Great service from the staff. Very helpful. The pour over selection is excellent and makes for a very clean brew.
author: Miguel P.

description:
Wonderful place to grab a coffee in the city! The affogato​ ​with blueberry and lavender gelato is simply perfect. They have a great atmosphere and delicious food. The only drawback is that it's often loud because of the popularity and location. 

It never bothered me until a day I was trying to work during lunch and I couldn't​ make any calls because of the background noise!  So, in short,​ it's perfect for​ food and coffee, but if you need a quiet space to work or study try Workshop instead.
author: Red D.

description: I used to frequent Equator a lot. This location is a bit smaller than the one at the Linkedin office, but I usually grab my drink and go. My favorite items here are probably the cold brew and chocolate chip cookie. From 4-6pm(closing), they have happy hour for their beers. They also have free stickers and pins.
author: Tabitha H.

description:
Spectacular...

I ordered a vanilla latte with cashew milk...wow delicious!

The foam art is high quality which matches the high quality of their espresso beans.  I'm also impressed they have cashew milk.  Super creamy and delicious...really complimented the espresso really well.

The place feels a bit small but it's really open and has a good vibe.  Will definitely return!


This place has been added to one of my favorite coffee shops in the bay.
author: Monica J.

description:
Hipster coffee joint? Check.

Tasty cappuccino? No check -- espresso had sour aftertaste & the cappuccino was made like a wet latte. 

Outdoor seating is available and some pastries, but I would take mazarine or coffee cultures over equator any day.
author: Kristie C.

description:
I love the Equator Coffees location on the UC Berkeley campus, so I was pretty disappointed with my experience here.

From the minute I walked in, there were flies everywhere. It was a warm day, so I could've let that one go. But when I was ordering my coffee and considering getting a pastry, I could also see a bunch of flies crawling all over the pastries in the case. Not really the most appetizing to look at. Plus the guy at the counter looked really uninterested and wasn't too friendly.

On the bright side, the cold brew coffee was good, as it is at the other location. Not sure if I'd be back though, considering the fly problem and the lack of good service.
author: Sara L.

description:
It's certainly refreshing to see an established roaster like Marin-based Equator take a chance with one of the dicier areas of the city. When I passed by it on a Market Street streetcar, I thought it was a mirage since I wouldn't have expected a welcoming cafe like this next to the Warfield Theater. Good things, however, appear to be coming to the neighborhood in threes between this place, Chai Bar by David Rio across Market, and Montesacro Pinseria Romana Enoteca on Stevenson. Each brings a much-needed freshness to an embattled area where police sirens and primal screams reflect more of the norm. There's no denying the rejuvenation that the Mid-Market corridor is starting to experience thanks to the likes of Twitter and Uber nearby.

There is patio seating cordoned off carefully from the passing foot traffic although this hasn't stopped the occasional local denizen from gawking awkwardly at the customers. The seats are concrete blocks, so I assume the proprietors are not looking for people to loiter for very long (photo: http://bit.ly/1KSttlh). There actually isn't much seating inside, just some stools against the left window counter and a standing counter to the right. The walls are covered with images of jungle foliage painted by local artist Mona Caron (photo: http://bit.ly/1IAy8ee), who painted the fanciful Market Street Railway Mural on Church Street. There's a surprising diversity of food items for sale: five different kinds of arepas, three salads, even fried chicken (photo: http://bit.ly/1T8sBih).

I was there just before a Yelp event at Montesacro and ordered the $4.75 16-oz Vanilla Latte (photo: http://bit.ly/1QHxrPw). It was smooth and not too sweet with an even richness that proved satisfying before my anticipated pinsa gorge. I like the idea behind the proposed "suspended coffee program" which encourages patrons to buy an extra coffee for someone less fortunate. That's the kind of practice that will help it build goodwill in an area that isn't used to showing it. By the way, there is indeed a restroom if you don't mind the labyrinth of making your way down to the basement of the Warfield building through the main lobby next door. Equator has really established a discernible foothold in this war zone, and I just hope they don't give up.

COFFEE - 4 stars...Blue Bottle-like richness in their lattes should draw in the caffeinated hipsters
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...an oasis with tropical palms on the walls
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...certainly nice enough
TOTAL - 4 stars...kudos for opening a cafe at the unenviable corner of 6th & Market
author: Ed U.

description: Equator is fast becoming one of my favorite coffee spots. This one is right on Market street which makes it a convenient spot to visit when you're out shopping at the westfield mall. I believe they are the only coffee shop in San Francisco to feature oat milk which is my new favorite milk substitute.
author: Justin S.

description:
This is my go to spot for work coffee - in the dirtiness that is often the 6th and Market area this is a shiny beautiful spot to brighten things up-

Equator has plenty of outdoor seating for nice days but also has plenty of room inside. Not a great place for working but definitely a good spot to have a chat or kick back for a few.

Their coffee is bold and strong without being bitter, and I'm a big fan of their Americanos. For a treat I also enjoy their cashew milk lattes. I haven't asked why they use cashew milk but it's a great option for those looking for a dairy free option.

They also have a nice selection of sandwiches/baked goods!
author: Elliott W.

description:
I was extremely excited to try Equator - newly opened and serving nitro! They don't have bathrooms.... uh. 

--------THE VERDICT ON NITRO?---------
- SIZE - 2 star: The nitro is TINY, like - made-for-children sized. 
- FLAVOR - 3 star: Surprisingly, not a fan of the flavor, which is weird because I like their brewed coffee.
- This was one of the foamiest nitros I've had, and the foam is my favorite part!

Equator nitro was small and mediocre, but I'd recommend at least one visit to experience how foamy it is. Actually, better yet, just stick with the regular coffee!
author: Jess C.

description:
Thought I'd drop in as I was out for a walk on Market Street. The outside seating is inviting. There was a bit of a line, but it moved quickly.
Service was ok, not welcoming but order taking.

Enjoy!
author: William M.

description: Rudest Barista ever. Refused my friends a bathroom key who had being working on the,streets outside beautifying the area in front of the shop. One said he could not touch the key because he served food, except he did not at all. The other person said to ask the cashier because you could only get the key from the cashier. Then he was told for customers only. Be nice to the people who take care of our city. He asked nicely and the staff here was rude and shitty. Home Skillet across the street was very accommodating when he asked there. 5 stars for Home Skillet!
author: Susan B.

description:
When asked if I wanted to head over to Equator for coffee,
I willingly agreed since I was in serious need of caffeine.
I mean how rare is it to find coffee from the Equator (wenk wenk).

As we walked into this newly open establishment on Market Street,
we were warmly welcomed at the entrance
and asked if we had been invited to their soft opening.
We had not, but the folks were nice enough to let us in anyway.

I'm also thinking they must of realized the blank zombie look on my face meant I was gonna try to force my way in regardless, jump behind the espresso machine, and make my own short cappuccino.
Problem avert.

Their short cappuccino was nice.  It was a robust and full bodied espresso with hints of dark chocolate and when combined with a silky warm microfoam milk (organic right?), it went down very smooth.
*I also liked that it was free : )

More importantly, now I can say I've had coffee at the Equator (kinda).

Well, until the day I actually go to the Equator for a coffee break,
I will gladly settle for this Equator on Market.
author: Dan B.

description: Seriously the best. It's clean and beautiful inside and their coffee is off the hook. I recommend their single origin brew - it's consistently delicious. I'm also quite addicted to their breakfast sandwich - get it with prosciutto!! To top it all off, their staff is super welcoming and friendly - especially Jacob and Francisco! Keep up the great work, guys.
author: Jim T.

description: $14.75 for two juices?!!!  I don't care if they have go plant the fruit trees by hand and squeeze it through their butt cheeks, there's no way in high heaven that they can justify that kind of pricing.  For them to still be in biz it's clear that there ate too many hipsters with too much money burning a hole in heir pockets.  Damn shame, just glad I wasn't buying ;)
author: P W.

description:
I have ordered the breakfast sandwich with prosciutto added several times and it seems there is an inconsistency in the quality of the sandwich. 

The last time I ordered it, it was quite dry and the toast was a bit burnt. The time before that it was perfectly cooked. Today, the egg was a rather burnt and extremely dry. I don't think I will be returning to this place, as with tax this was over $8. That may sound cheap given that this is the city, but I believe that it is important for restaurants and cafes to care about their product and customer. It seems this place cares more about the atmosphere and their hipster image than the actual product being sold.
author: Ashley M.

description:
Tried out Equator Coffee & Tea on Market.  It's not too far from The Hall in the Tenderloin.

I tried out the Classic Shakerato $3.75 - it's an espresso with some ice shaken in a cocktail shaker.  It was ok, tasted strong.

I hope they can make me an iced latte shaken up!!  Let's all demand for it ok?  I know Bica in Oakland does that and it's yummy.

B. got just poured coffee and he thought it was strong.  He had to add milk.

Pastries from Sandbox Bakery - I didn't get any.

Some places to sit inside, and there's tables/stools outside.
author: Ann L.

description:
Know why your yard is empty of boyz? Bc my $4.50 Scrizzatch Caramel Shakerato #ididntmakethatworduptheydid brought 'em all to MY yard. Beezy.

Thought I was just here for coffee... till I saw the other food / tea / beer & wine(!) havin' parts of the menu. Dang.
author: Dan B.

description:
Equator coffee in the city. Thank goodness. My marin favorite finally opened an outpost in sf when they opened this spot a few years ago. 

Definitely in a "transitional" neighborhood, meaning don't leave your cell phone on your table! They have outside seating and it's a great place to people watch. Plenty of tourists and techies going to work. This store has super friendly staff. Very outgoing and they play really fun music. My espresso is perfect every time. Usually made by a barista with very bright hair. She is super talented. 

The breakfast sandwich is really delicious. Could be spicier IMHO, but still a win for breakfast.
author: Marcus Y.

description:
Friendy staff? Yes.
Knowledgeable staff that brew correctly? Yes.
Great selection of coffees? Yes.

When I'm in SF for business I make sure to stop into Equator. They typically have two to three coffees that they offer for pour overs and the quality of the coffee and roast are top notch. The lady working at the store was very friendly, knowledgeable and seemed genuinely interested in our conversation. I've had countless pour overs from this location and all have been delicious. 

Be sure to stop in here the next time you are looking for a great cup of coffee with a great experience.
author: Billy C.

description: Stopped to grab lunch, the cashier seemed pretty rude. She was rolling her eyes at me, raising her eyebrows and being all sorts of unfriendly. I get it, maybe you are having a rough day, but seriously I didn't come in for your bad attitude.
author: Erica Z.

description: The coffee is good. Some of the staff have some real anger issues though. One of the  guys there will get irrationally upset with you if you somehow manage to mistake the bathroom door. Instead of having a sign to walk the customers into the bathroom, they have an angry employee who will make you feel like you just did something really really wrong if you accidentally don't see the sign they didn't write. Like I said coffee is good but management would be better off by making sure they don't hire angry people.
author: Avinash R.

description:
I went back for their coffee... it was delicious and didn't cost me $14.

+1 star!
author: Jennifer K.

description:
On my quest to try a different coffee shop every time in the Union Square/FiDi area, today we ventured down Market to 5th/6th to try Equator Coffee which opened less than a week ago. Walking in you're first greeted at the door and handed a menu by a very friendly gentleman and then enter into a very hipster shop with no seating and a live dj playing music in the corner. Quite the way to start the day.

In addition to standard coffee bar options, they also have fruit squashes (handcrafted muddled fruit sodas), shakeratos (shakened sweetened flavored ice espressos), arepas, noshes, salads, yogurts and sandbox baked goods. Great selection and I especially enjoyed the classic shakerato. 

On top of liking what they offered for food, drinks and atmosphere, I really appreciate the addition of a nice establishment like this to the mid-market area. I feel that with more businesses like this in addition to the upcoming mall, this area could go from being a sketchy neighbor to the tenderloin to a classier extension of the union square, upper market area. Hopefully this trend continues.

Overall, Equator was great and I plan on coming back in the future. In this part of the city for coffee, morning snacks and a dose of early morning dj to wake you up, this is "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description: Noticed this cafe this week. Great place to hang out after work!
author: Julio B.

description:
Do not buy the quinoa cabbage salad. 

It's extremely bitter and hard to eat. I choked down a couple bites and threw it away.
author: Megan M.

description: Cute coffee shop with good coffee but doesn't quite match up to popular spots like Phil's or Sightglass. I like Equator's coffee but I don't love it either.
author: Valerie L.

description: The coffee and food here are great! The service is exceptional. I would recommend the breakfast sandwich with chorizo... awesome seasoning! Their baked goods also look amazing... maybe next time because I am definitely coming back!
author: Charlotte T.

description: I had the scratch caramel latte based on the recommendation from another yelper.  It was a rich,  delightfully bittersweet cup of coffee.
author: Stephanie S.

description: So my friends and I took a Lyft here and when we arrived, our Lyft driver questioned where we were headed....because we pulled up and it just happens that Equator coffee is next to a gentlemen's club LOL WAY TO GO. So we walked on into Equator and we were greeted by the beautiful leafy mural on the wall. Super modern, clean cut atmosphere. I noticed that they sell quite a number of food items, wine, and beer. We ordered hot milk tea, scratch caramel latte, and iced house made vanilla latte with cashew milk. The cashew milk was delicious however the cashew flavors are so strong, so I would suggest that if you want to taste the vanilla (or whatever you order) but you're lactose, then you should probably get it with soy. That cashew just overpowers all other flavors. Still really good though! The caramel was also quite delicious. The milk tea was a surprising one to see, but really it is a tea latte and not those asian milk teas you think of. They put in a sprig on some kind of herb which made the whole thing very floral. This is definitely a solid coffee spot if you're in the neighborhood!
author: Maleah M.

description:
Cool little place and probably the best coffee you can buy on Market Street.

Staff was very nice and very talkative. They seem to really like their jobs and their company.
author: Nicholas L.

description:
Attitude = minus 10. My latte was liuke warm, and when I asked if they had some way to heat it I was told
"No." No offer to remake either. Blueberry muffin was nice though.
author: Ann K.

description:
I like really tasty, full-bodied coffee but get super tired (maybe hypocritically?) of the hipster snobbery you find in so many good Bay Area coffee places. I recently started working around the corner from Equator and was pretty happy to run into it one day before work. 

They open earlier than everyone else. It is always really clean and upbeat. There's always a seat open before work (because most of the crowd are grab-n-go). And the workers are pretty down-to-earth and friendly, but not the fake kind of friendly. 

And the coffee on it's own (I always get the latte) is really good quality. Nothing is over roasted and the foam is done just right. I've also tried their cheddar and chives scone, which was just the right amount of moistness and saltiness.

Also--really dig the kitteh stickers. Pretty dope. Hoping they don't notice I take one like, every, time. If they do, they're pretty chill about it!

One of my other favorite things about the place is they don't chase off or call the police on the many homeless people in the area. That's a rare and humane quality in downtown San Francisco and I really appreciate it. It is probably part of the company culture because the business is supposed to be built on low-impact type ethics. (I don't really buy into that "good capitalism" stuff, but at least they roast locally.) 

Anyways, I've tried a lot of coffee places in the area and this one is one of my favorites.
author: Ramona R.

description:
Coffee is okay - I wasn't very impressed for the price. The vibe of the cafe is cute and hip. 

Service is great. Not much too eat so just keep that in mind.
author: Carina M.

description:
Equator's cold brew coffee with a dash of Remedy's cashew milk is the best way to end the work day and to bring in the weekend.

There's been a number of coffee and cafes opening up in the area recently - but Equator is probably the only one - that has directly inspired me to make an expedition just to try their well sourced tea and coffee brews.

If you're not familiar with Equator - I highly recommend you making your own pilgrimage soon. Equator is committed to using superior ingredients and the best machinery in all of their extraordinary products. Thomas Keller has exclusively brewed and served Equator drip coffee at The French Laundry in Yountville, CA for a number of years now. Equator even carries some specific and unique chef blends like French Laundry's Estate blend and Jardiniére's Organic Fair Trade Blend. You know that you are drinking a quality product when world renowned chefs are excited to promote it - beside their food masterpieces.

In addition to coffee and tea - Equator also carries food options. They have healthy Remedy bars to go, as well as organic yogurt parfaits and well sourced salads and sandwiches. 

If you value excellence when it comes to your drinks and food - Equator knows what's up.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description: Coffee is amazing. The location is great. It is a nice place. They have an outdoor seating. I love their iced lattes. I usually get the croissant as well. And I am never disappointed. Defiantly one of my favorite places.
author: Yana B.

description: It took 20 mins to get my breakfast sandwich (bread, egg, and avocado...) & it wasn't that busy. BUT the gluten free bread I ordered with it was actually delicious.
author: Rob M.

description: Had a solid almond latte! Their almond butter and jam sandwich was delicious and the staff was very friendly!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I have three words for you: Fancy. Tea. Drinks. The Oolong milk tea is really good: sweet, aromatic, just enough caffeine, and made with soy if you want it.

I have two more words for you: Gay. Pride. All the queer business owners I know are I whipped up into a frenzy about this place because Maria Contreras-Sweet, US Administrator of the US Small Business Administration, just presented  cofounders, Helen Russell and Brooke McDonnell with the 2016 Small Business of the Year, making this little coffee shop the first (out) LGBT-owned company to win the prestigious award.

It's a great place to write, with lovely outdoor seating. The service is spectacular. If you use the restroom, you get to explore the bowels of the historic Warfield building next door. 

What more could you possibly want?
author: Kristy L.

description: Ive been an equator fan for a while now as they supply TKRG's restos; French Laundry, Bouchon, Ad Hoc, etc. coffee is always top notch but today was a tea day. The menu is setup high so i had to look around for a bit to find what i wanted. I think that translated to me looking lost to the cashier. But when asked a straight up black iced tea was the choice. Solid smooth and refreshing. Workers are friendly and the space is urban with rustic nature art. The guy working the front patio is doing his hardest to pull people in old school, like the last if the Arabbers
author: Kim N.

description: I LOVE that new things are showing up on mid-Market! Whispers of more coffee shops have been abound, and when Equator opened it's doors for the first time this morning, I got the warm and fuzzies that this whole area is about to change (warm and fuzzy probably isn't how most people would describe mid-Market either). In any case, Equator's space is beautiful with high ceilings and very friendly staff.  I had their single origin brewed coffee, which was just OK to be honest. What I should have done was asked for one of their pour overs instead.  Lesson learned for next time.  Their menu looks extensive, and I'm always partial to a place that sells delicious looking pastries. I love the energy from Equator, I'll be back to explore my pour over options soon.
author: Lisa I.

description:
Great service, very good coffee. Equator's roasts are not quite on the same level as Ritual and Four Barrel in the City, but are still very good. If you are shopping in Union Square, this and Mazarine are your two best bets for good coffee.
Not a lot of options for purchasing beans in the store, but what was available was very good. Additionally, I had a poor experience ordering from them online, and their service team was awesome, and did everything they could to make it right the same day.
author: Brett B.

description: Their coffee speaks for itself, but I wish they had more food options that aren't as sugar-infused.
author: Keanu B.

description:
I wouldn't consider myself to be a coffee connoisseur, more like a coffee novice, but I can tell that Equator's coffee is better than most!  I personally like a more sweeter flavor so I would recommend the vanilla latte with cashew milk.   Yums!  

The staff are super attentive and friendly.  I've asked a few times what they recommended and they are knowledgeable to the different types of flavors and subtleties in the drinks.  They have so many beverage choices that I'll be trying different drinks for months!
author: Christy Y.

description:
Equator is a really nice and quaint coffee shop on Market across from Blick Art Materials.

They serve coffee, tea, wine, beer, cocktails, salads, parfaits, and even heavier eats. 

There's indoor high chair seating and outdoor tables in a little mini patio area.
author: Yanni L.

description: Equator was one of the coffee shops I wanted to checkout while in SFO.  The shop is in/borders the Tenderloin neighborhood.  There are some small tables inside and larger tables outside.  I had a cortado and a cappuccino.  Both drinks were very good.  The cortado seemed a little bigger than usual.   A short walk from here is another good coffee shop to try, George and Lennie.
author: Brent W.

description:
Equator made me do it! When I heard that Equator had opened up in Mid-Market, I braved the "other side" to cross over past 5th Street. I know that Mid-Market is currently hopping, but no one ever really enjoys that walk, even in broad daylight. 

The space is close to Show Dogs and The Hall and is small but beautifully open. Murals on the walls, baristas front and center. It won't be the kind of space where you can sit and work, although there is some outdoor seating. The people who work there are incredibly welcoming and are happy to recommend drinks on their extensive menu. I was eyeing the Scratch Caramel Shakerato (made with whipping cream!) and happily opted for the drink. 

I've always loved Equator for their mellow, smooth brew, and they certainly didn't disappoint. Not a hint of sourness or acidity that I dislike so much in coffee. I gulped down my smooth smooth Shakerato in record time and found myself wishing for more...

I'm looking forward to coming back for their Cold Brew and there are plenty of fruity and tea drinks for non-caffeine addicts as well. I was surprised at their extensive "Nosh" options, which I'm sure would be great for those working nearby.
author: Kate M.

description:
I'm excited that a new coffee shop has popped up on Mid-Market. And it's not just coffee, but they have a menu of baked goods, salads, yogurt parfaits, and arepas (savory & salty) so you have a wide selection of healthy and non-healthy options. The food looks a bit pricey for size (pastries and salads), but I guess it's par-for-the-course in SF. I haven't tried any of the food quite yet, but the arepas were intriguing and I will be back to try those. There are about 2 sweet versions of arepas, one with almond butter, and savory ones that have proscuitto, arugula, and burrata, one with chorizo and parmesan, and a few other flavors.

I had a single origin coffee ($2.25) that was really good. They have cashew milk, and what I assume was regular milk & cream (there were 2 metal carafes that were not labeled). The cashew milk was great with my coffee.

There are a few tables outside for hanging out, but no inside seating, so don't come here expecting to be able to eat inside if it's cold, or to read a book / work on your laptop inside.

All in all, a great addition to the neighborhood with a wide selection of drinks and food. The decor inside is beautiful with high ceilings, concrete & exposed pipes, wood & a lot of white. I'll be back to try more things!
author: Christina L.

description:
Holy crap this place is fantastic. The staff is just so friendly. I'm not sure when I came to expect terrible service at coffee shops, but I'm always left pleasantly surprised by Equator. Everyone who works there is lovely and conversational and just plain nice. 

Add to that 10/10 coffee and amazing pastries.
author: Claire M.

description: This was a great spot to stop for breakfast! The sandwiches are delicious, the staff was friendly and you GOTTA love the people watching from the street! Enjoy!
author: Shawn H.

description: Lovely selection of coffees, lattes, and other caffeinated beverages. Also I was surprised by their collection of breakfast/brunch sandwiches. I ordered the breakfast frittata sandwich, which had avocado and some spicy pepper sauce. It exceeded my expectations for a coffee shop sandwich; it was delicious. I also got a latte with it, such was very tasty. There's limited indoor seating at their location in downtown SF, so it might not be ideal to come in and do work depending on what time you come it/how busy is it. Overall, I'd come back!
author: Jen A.

description: Great place to sit and enjoy! I ordered an espresso which was good quality. They also gave me a small glass of sparkling water with it, which was a nice touch. I came there early morning to get some caffeine and studying done and was very pleased with the atmosphere. Good music!
author: Liam E.

description: Strong amazing coffee! Usually places charge a lot for almond/soy milk and here it's free. Love it. They could clean occasionally though, the iPad I had to touch and sign on was FILTHY and the floors need some help
author: Marisa L.

description:
I have the ultimate privilege of working right across the street from Equator. Before they moved in, I was going to Blue Bottle, but the day Equator opened and I had one of their lattes I vowed to never go back to Blue Bottle!! 

The coffee is amazing, the staff is wonderful, and the vibes are on point. Every morning I look forward to seeing the baristas and I know without the shadow of a doubt that my coffee is going to be made just the way I like it.

To those of you who say its too expensive, I have two things to say:

1. You are paying for QUALITY ingredients.
2. You can get 16 oz iced/hot cups here. Blue Bottle will charge you the same brice for a latte but it's half the size.
author: Austin B.

description: Had a great cup of coffee here. They were friendly and very informative about the different beans and roasts..
author: S W.

description:
I love this place for so many reasons.   Proximity to my office,  super nice staff,  and excellent espresso drinks.   It's the place where I don't need to add sugar because the coffee is that good and doesnt need it.

And I forgot another reason: cashew milk!
author: Tamar D.

description: Poor service, employee had an attitude when I asked a question about coffee flavors and pricing. I won't go back here! No star!
author: Carol B.

description:
At some point I've said, "Do you have anything larger than your large cup?" I get my latte here almost every morning and that large cup never make it to work which is just a block away!

Like I said, I come here almost every morrning for my latte. So soon as they see me, they'd start making my latte and to double check that i still want the same thing, they'd just state my order for me, I don't need to tell them what I want anymore, all I have to do is pay! 

If you ever wonder how I want my latte and why I can't stop sipping it, this is the specific: single origin (a buck more-worth it), regular milk and large. Simple syrup, optional. Boom!
author: Lora M.

description: Happy for this new and hot coffee spot. Cozy and unique interior, clean (including the seating outside), kind staff and amazing coffee. I still can't believe they have cashew milk! For dairy they use organic Straus Creamery milk, half and half and Greek yogurt. They also have paleo snack/ energy bars.
author: Sandra K.

description: Love this place! It's been bookmarked on my yelp for a long time and I'm so happy to be able to finally check in and feel that satisfaction! Aesthetic was everything. Loved the music they played and the color scheme (white, grey, green and accents of red). I got the snow leopard pour-over (recommended by my cashier) and Sean got a vanilla latte. I'm pretty sure both were 10 oz, which is fairly reasonable (around $4). The pour-over was good, but not that good. It had a slightly sour aftertaste but was pretty strong and yummy. Sean liked his vanilla latte too (comes with the usual cute leaf design with milk). Overall really loved this place and aesthetic, fairly close to Powell station and bus stations (always convenient), so will def be back!!
author: Kyle D.

description: Friendly staff and a nice selection of veggie sandwich options (they also have chorizo and prosciutto for the meat-eaters). Also the gluten free bread they offer is hearty and tasty. The vibe is pretty standard as far as coffee chains go, but I particularly like that this location is bright and open. Great place to work if not too busy- otherwise reaching one of the few available outlets may be tough.
author: Bekah S.

description: "Omg this is good shit" my friend exclaimed as she took her first sip. I only tried the Shakerato Classic and caramel ones, would highly recommend either-- classic if you prefer less sweet and caramel if you'd want something with a little more sweetness.
author: Atiya B.

description: The manager at this location, previously the manager in Mill Valley is the sweetest. The staff has always been incredibly friendly and the coffee is the best in town... that's saying a lot in a town like San Francisco, but forreal. A stop for any commuter or coffee enthusiast.
author: Natalie O.

description:
If you are getting your coffee someplace else in this neighborhood, you're doing it wrong.

Equator is amazing! The coffee, the staff and the food are all wonderful. (seriously the food is worlds better than what oher coffee shops have and even better than most lunch spots).

They have their own roasting facility in Marin.  They are very conscious about how they treat the coffee growers who supply the beans and their local staff. I think their staff has better wages and benefits than many senior business people.

And somehow they bring in all that quality at reasonable prices!

Also - they have beer and wine.  Why don't all coffee shops have beer and wine??
author: lisa g.

description: As a basis to judge my coffee shops, I always get black coffee. It was delicious and didn't taste like it had been sitting for hours. I also ordered a vanilla latte, which was absolutely delightful with real vanilla. Not overly sweet, either. It was a lovely day, so my group decided to sit outside. The inside seating is quite limited. Also, the wifi cut in and out, so coming here might be a risk to do work on a cold/not lovely day.
author: Kendall S.

description:
The coffee is nothing to write home about and overpriced. The thing you don't expect us to get guff from the baristas when taking a brief pause from work to have some expensive coffee. 

My irritating encounter is as follows: 
I heard them calling out a drink on the bar and thought it sounded good. I ordered it and went to wait for the drink. After a while the barista asked what I ordered. Upon hearing my order she accused me of not paying attention and acted very annoyed. When I tried to explain that I was in line when she was calling out the drink they ended up poring out she argued with me and then dismissively gave me my drink with an "ok whatever." The behavior was so unprofessional. Now, rather than getting back to work, I am irritated enough that I am writing a review and regretting the tip I left on my card before this interaction.
author: Erik H.

description:
One of the best tea lattes I've ever had. I got the honey orchid tea latte (pretty sure that's what it was called) and it came beautifully garnished with rosemary on top. Just the right amount sweetness and creamy and wonderful. I've been to Equator a few times and that's still the only thing I've gotten because it was so good. 

Of course it was egregiously expensive and a pretty small serving, but I think that just (unfortunately) comes with the territory of these type of coffee shops.

My friend got one of their specialty drinks with whiskey in it, and wow, that too was incredible. 

Great for a splurge but don't think I'll make it a regular stop.
author: Marilyn M.

description: I've had equator at SFO airport and agree one of the best. However this location is filthy!!! Maybe 4 or 5 customers and the floor inside and outdoor patio area were covered in trash. Gal working register was texting. Time to lean, time to clean. Also with doors propped open the place was infested with flies.  Guess I'll stick to airport.
author: Tony P.

description: I've been ordering Equator coffee online for years. I haven't found many that compare. I was recently in San Francisco and we tried several coffee houses and this was excellent and our favorite.  When I'm next in The City I will definitely be back.
author: Terry G.

description:
A very nice addition to the Mid-Market area.  My friend and I were on our way to the Warfield, but we decided to stop in to check out Equator, a Marin based coffee shop.  I'm so glad we did!  The coffee here is freshly made each hour and they serve pastries and other baked goods from Sandbox, a local SF bakery.  They also serve beer and wine, a great place to get a drink or snack before concerts and shows.  

The staff were extremely friendly, especially Joseph and Joseph.  Even after a long day, they were both happy to talk about the coffee and answer all the questions my friend had about Equator.  :)

The iced herbal hibiscus tea was delicious and just what I needed before my concert at the Warfield.  I will definitely be back here.
author: Wendy S.

description:
I love this new trendy, delicious and friendly coffee place on Market Street! The place is not real big so there's not a lot of seating inside with some of it spilling outside. Perhaps enough room for 10 or so people... The coffee itself is simply amazing! I'm somewhat of a snob when it comes to ordering my latte, and I certainly don't go to chains like Peet's or Starbucks, but I do have my favorites and this one definitely ranks up among them now. 

I also ordered a Mango Oat Bar which is interesting because I'm not a huge fan of oats or mangoes, but it just looked so good. One bite and I was in love! This is the way fruit bars should be done!

I'm quite happy with not only the service but also the quality of food and it was a very pleasant ambience. The location isn't the greatest but I know that the areas around there are all trying to bring up that area to a bit of a higher quality, and I think this café is definitely helping pave the way for that.
author: Jordan M.

description:
I had a delicious and beautiful Cortado here. Service was exceptional and the store itself is minimalist and clean, which you'd expect from a brand new shop. Equator has long been one of my favorite coffees so I'll be picking up whole bean coffee as well. 

I also had the opportunity to try their in-house sour cherry soda which was equal parts tart and refreshing. 

Great place to grab a coffee on the way to work - and hopefully faster than Machine just down Market. Not the best for work time as the tables and chairs are also minimalist - in other words, aren't comfortable for long. I assume by design.
author: Seth S.

description:
Really friendly people working there! The place on market gets a lot of natural light that filters in the cafe and the flowers on the tables make a nice touch.

The Americano I got there was not acidic at all, it was nice and smooth!
I also got an AB&J (almond butter and jelly) open faced which was good, but I think at $6.50 for one slice...it's a tad bit overpriced.

For getting work done, I can't see myself getting any serious work done here, but it'd be a nice place to get some leisurely reading done!
author: Sean S.

description:
A DJ at 8am ? Awesome.  I love the vibe here. It has an industrial feel, and there's no indoor seating, but there is a blocked off patio area (though it's a long a semi sketchy stretch of Market). 

For breakfast, they have arepas: 
- Prosciutto and burrata 
- Chorizo and parmesan 

We also had a cappuccino and a cashew milk cafe au lait (no soy or almond milk).  The top it off with a beet mimosa ...

At $34, it wasn't cheap for a coffee shop breakfast, but the coffee and food are both really solid. It's hard not to order food when you smell the aroma of food when you walk in.  It's nice to have another breakfast option
author: Marilyn T.

description:
I'm a huge fan of Equator Coffee, and have been drinking their coffee for about 2 years now, but I had never been to one of their shops.  I consider myself a coffee connoisseur, and prefer good good quality, single origin, black coffee (French press is my go to, but pour over works great also).  So, when a local coffee shop further down the peninsula and closer to where I live started using Equator Coffee for their pour overs, I instantly fell in love!  Equator easily falls in my top 5 (maybe even top 3!) favorite coffee roasters.  So, when I had some time to kill in SF, I was excited to finally go to one of their shops, which happened to be this one on Market.  It's a small location with a few seats inside and outside.  You can't hold the small size against them as reality in SF is stupid expensive!  (And they are in a prime location!)  I was on a tight budget at the time, so chose to go for a cup of brewed coffee.  I knew it wouldn't taste as good as a pour over, and at $2.75 which is cheaper than most specialty coffee shops, I was slightly apprehensive about how good it would taste... but I was pleasantly surprised at the quality of flavor that it carried for being "brewed coffee" and not a "pour over."  
The shop was clean, and had a cool look to it.  Other reviews mention flies... I was also there on a hot day, and didn't experience any flies, so maybe they fixed the problem?  There are some outlets inside and free wifi, which was great as I needed to get some work done on my laptop.  They had some free samples available of some pastries, which were delicious.  Their pastry and food options look great... I need to come back when I'm not on such a tight budget! haha.  The baristas were friendly when I ordered... I only gave 4/5 stars as I felt they lacked that top-notch, homey-feel, customer service you get in your local coffee shops... but given their location it's understandable, and it was still good customer service.  Next time I'm in SF, I will definitely be back!
author: Eric D.

description: Their cold brew coffee is extremely caffeinated and delicious. One of my favorite iced coffees in the area, if not the favorite. Only thing that is unfortunate is the line at 8:50am on weekdays!
author: Amy Y.

description: My fave coffee bean after St. Franks.
author: Beril Y.

description: I love that they have cashew milk as an option. The combo with espresso is great. Everyone is also very friendly :) will be coming back soon!
author: Sandra S.

description: Not sure what I got but it's was super bombbbbbbb! Walk in and a sweet smell of coffee hits my nose!!!! Great atmosphere here, most definitely coming back from LA
author: Julieann N.

description: An oasis in the midst of limited options. Enjoyed a delicious breakfast sandwich and  coffee at their outdoor seating where the sun was shining perfectly. You can even get champagne here!
author: Lena R.

description:
Great coffee, vibes. Service was friendly as..!
Vanilla iced espresso is delicious, baristia knows her coffee and took the time to tailor it!
author: Rob C.

description:
Came here because paradoxically enough, Homeskillet had a huge line out the door. So we decided to go across the street and grab coffees and pastries from the newly opened Equator.

Brewed Coffee: Tasted normal. I guess you can't really taste "free-trade" or "organic" in coffee... so I don't know what I expected? Also, there's organic cashew milk that you can pour into it, which is interesting because I've never tried cashew milk. Stick with the normal milk or cream though.

Arepas: We got the candied pecan. Very sweet. Very small. Tasted unhealthy and not worth it. 

White cheddar and mushroom croissant: Meh. Wasn't warmed up and just tasted absolutely mediocre. Guess I won't be trying Sandbox bakery anytime soon. That being said, I spent the entire week in a croissant fiending mode and tried a new croissant shop every morning. This was not the worst (focaccia on 8th and Mission is). 

Not sure if I'll be back. Expensive for what it was.
author: Sylvia L.

description:
really good coffee!
I'm rooting for this roaster. They were smart to get really good at roasting before trying to operate cafes, which is the opposite of what a lot of local coffee companies do. 

Very careful pour-over technique resulting in perfect cups of coffee via Hario V60 paper filter drip cones on scales. 
High points for offering really good pour-over decaf. This decaf Ethiopian was so good, I was skeptical it was even decaf. The regular pour-over Ethiopian was also delicious. 
I appreciate how this roaster roasts a little more medium than places like Four Barrel. The single origin coffee is bright and clear without being mouth-puckeringly sour. 

The people working here were friendly and helpful - not coffee snobs at all. 
Thanks to Equator for making high quality coffee more accessible.
author: RK W.

description:
Epic ampersands.

A&B: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8vwvgBWVGr0

AB&J: Almond butter, bananas and sour cherry jam inside flatbread. Each bite was better than the last. Absolutely outstanding and so very worth the $6.50.

Paired with a sweet and surprisingly not heavy Strauss whole milk yogurt, blueberry, granola and honey parfait. Reasonable for $6.50 as well.

Also had an impressively smooth, no need to add anything Americano. Passion for beans is their purpose and is reflected in the staff's enthusiasm. Priced right at $2.75.

Loved the signature red accents. But not as much as I loved that ampersand.

Both get five stars.
author: Jason B.

description: Between the selection of teas, the availability of cashew milk, the cute interior, and the nice service Equator Coffee has a pull that keeps me coming back! It is something to look forward to on walks home from work to pick up a cup of tea to keep my hands warm when the SF winds turn and just as great a stop on my way to work for an iced coffee to keep me cool/ get my morning pick-me-up.
author: Shannon H.

description: Delicious cappuccino. Friendly staff. Large for a cappuccino. Don't love the location but easy access.
author: Shiloh H.

description: Another addition to the list of coffee shops. I had a cappuccino but my friend had a iced drink which was called a shaker I think and that tasted great. Will be back to try one of those myself !
author: Priyanka P.

description: Pricey but good coffee. Service is friendly. I tried the caramel latte - it was nice, with the right amount of sweet. Will stop by the next time I am around.
author: Anwar H.

description:
If I wanted an attitude and terrible service, I would have gone to Blue Bottle. 

Equator Coffee on Market is beautiful. The place is a gem and adds a great deal of value to the community. 

They offer a full range of snacks and the initial engagement with their team was outstanding. 

This all ended when I asked their Barista a question. 

Needless to say, it went downhill quickly. 

Seriously disappointing, but I'd rather know what I'm walking into at Blue Bottle. 

Drop the attitude and glorified coffee maker and I'll think about trying it again. 

P.S. These comments do not reflect the kind gentleman pouring drip coffee.
author: Jeffrey D.

description: So glad I found this place. They were very friendly and the coffee and ambiance were great! It's the perfect early morning treat to start the day.
author: Crispin M.

description: The best espresso roast in the Bay Area. We had been buying their beans and stopping at their shop in Marin for years, and now come here bi-weekly. Great, friendly staff too. Highly recommend for those who appreciate a good espresso (a real one, not the watery stuff you find most places). So happy to have this spot near my work!
author: Ashley S.

description:
Nice little place that's open until 7pm and serves a refreshingly unique mix of drinks and snacks. 

I came in here just before closing and the baristas who were cleaning up patiently made me the ginger lemon mint squash (kind of like a homemade sparkling soda), which I loved! My manfriend got a cold brew on tap and said it was fabulous (not sure if those were his exact words but he drank it pretty quickly). We also tried the pumpkin chocolate chip bread and it was pretty tasty. In the meantime the ice in mine melted and made a surprisingly delicious second drink!

I imagine that this place doesn't rush during the day, as many of their drinks look like they require more work than those at other places, but I enjoyed mine enough to plan a return visit to try other beverages and food. 

Not bad for our first experience!
author: Mel L.

description: Great coffee and a nice change from Starbucks. The employees were really nice and there were some good choices for breakfast. It was better and a LOT less crowded than Starbucks in the morning. Definitely busy but it didn't take long to get a coffee.
author: Brian R.

description: I had a latte with cashew milk here and the coffee was amazing!!! not many places offer cashew milk, which is great. Also, the staff was super helpful and friendly. The only downside is it's definitely still a "transitional" neighborhood, but that's what city life is.  I'd recommend.  Wifi was prettygood, though I did have a few blips where it was slow.
author: Marcos S.

description: Scratch caramel latte was excellent.  Shakerato was new to me and really enjoyed.  The young lady behind the counter was very courteous and the service was excellent.  Sometimes the folks behind the coffee machine do a very good impression of an automaton, not so here.  Very capable lady who handled a difficult situation with a homeless person with tact.
author: Ram S.

description: Great staff, great coffee and good vibe. All drinks are crafted with an attention to detail and quality.  A++
author: Angela S.

description: They've got really friendly staff, cold brew nitro coffee, and Johnny Doughnuts on Friday. This place is awesome.
author: Ariana L.

description: The coffee here is outstanding, and I'm now in love with cashew milk in my coffee (it was really a revelation). I would, however, have to question the two $$ designation. I know it's SF, but the prices here are........a little high here.
author: Frank A.

description: I guess she wast having a very good morning this morning because I asked her how was she doing and never got a answer. The little short girl at the register with the glasses is rude and will rush you if you take to long don't go to her she not helpful at all. This location needs to do better I won't return! There are way too many other coffee bars serving better espresso drinks and they have the service to go along with it.
author: Michael R.

description: I travel to SF biweekly and this is a new hidden gem. Great coffee, amazing GF food options and the staff are very kind. Found my new coffee spot when I'm in the area!
author: Jehan M.

description:
really good variety, 7am-7pm is amazing too

some cons
staff is friendly but almost overly friendly
the space is really wide open with short bushes outside and huge glass windows, so its not so much of a retreat as it is a pit-stop. in the future i would love to see visual blocks for nice seating in the patio area, and visual blocks from the employees behind the counter
author: Cara D.

description: Equator is my new favorite coffee shop. It's located between 5th and 6th of market right by the tenderloin. The area can be a bit rough. Sometimes hobos would sit at their outdoor seatings but equator has security guards who keeps tab on them. Their coffee is amazing. My favorite is the sweeten iced shakerato. It pretty much a sweeten iced expresso. It's rich in flavor and it's so creamy. It is best expresso drink i have had. I have tried their lattes and ice drinks, they were good but not amazing. Equator also has a great selection of teas that are of quality and unique. If you haven't had coffee from there, it's a must try.
author: Tina L.

description: I was so happy to find a coffee shop near The Warfield where I could sit down, have a bite to eat and a coffee before the doors opened.  The sopes are great!  Thank you for staying open until 7 pm!
author: Josephine G.

description:
There's a lot of third wave coffee shops in san francisco and their respective coffees are all good in their own right. That being said, Equator serves a high quality great coffee and the only thing that separates them from the rest is their great and friendly customer service. I used to go at Blue Bottle which is a few minutes away but their customer service sucks. Yes, their coffee is really good but why would i still patronize them if they are unfriendly. 

One of your barista i think her name is Nea, she is really helpful and i commend her customer service skills.  She is really knowledgeable and she knows what she's doing.
author: Ar L.

description: Wow wow!! The cashew milk latte is the best latte of my life. That's saying a lot because I've had espresso all over the world. The staff is friendly and this is a prime spot to sit and people watch out front.
author: Kris R.

description: Fast and easy with great service and a solid Americano, right on market. If you're walking by, take the time to stop. Only went in by chance and actually felt like writing a review since there's so much competition around. Weren't super coffee elitist like some, but very clean inside. I'll go again if I happen to meander by, but I would go more if there was one in the east bay.
author: Chris P.

description: I don't understand the behavioral economics of having only a 10oz and 16oz option. Medium is such a delightful way to start the day. And they are out of soy milk at 9:30am on a Saturday. This is a hipster honeypot that has just bilked me into cashew milk and out of $12.00.
author: Jude O.

description: Delicious! Just had the Almond Butter Banana and Jelly sandwich and it was fire! Definitely coming back to try the coffee and other food items!
author: Ben N.

description:
Very mixed review here. I used to come almost every single afternoon for a large chai latte because Equator makes by far the best chai latte I have ever tasted -- and I have tasted a few. It was also the most expensive I had ever tasted -- $4.75 per cup. More expensive than any local cafe by a dollar or more. Worth it to me. 
Alas, when they raised their coffee prices a few months ago to reflect the sharp rise in the price of coffee beans, they decided to raise price of the chai lattes as well. I'm not sure why. I guess because they thought they could get away with it. I suppose they probably have. But it really irritated me. It sounds absurd to quit a cafe over a 25 cent price hike, but it also seems greedy to hike the price of an already ridiculously expensive drink by 25 cents. I suddenly felt like a chump and just like that I stopped drinking Equator chai lattes. I never even think about going in there any more and after the first few days, I have not missed my afternoon drink. I am probably a little skinner and am definitely a little richer. However! If you want to try a great chai latte, this is the place. And it's a nice place, very comfortable and popular and people who love coffee love this coffee. There you have it, my mixed review.
author: Jennifer R.

description: The wait is long for a single espresso drink. I ordered the shakerato. I was cursing t myself after waiting for almost 15 minutes for my order, so much that when I finally got it, I swore never to return. But then I had my first sip of the classic flavor shakerato. It instantly changed y mind. Yes, it's that good. TOTALLY worth the long wait.
author: Pony R.

description:
Equator Coffees & Tees offers Colombian Arepas!!!  Those are no Colombian Arepas................ not even close. I know, I am Colombian. I was so excited I could have an arepa, and so down when I tested the final product. I had a $7.50 chorizo with avocado kind of corn tortilla. Maybe closer to Venezuela's arepas, but not really.

Having said that, whatever concoction I ate it was good!!!! 

Please do not call it an arepa, Colombians would like to see a real Colombian restaurant in the Bay. We may go once to your location and never return.
author: Marcela V.

description: In SF on a work trip and I have been going to blue bottle. Not anymore, found my new morning coffee stop. Don't be frightened that it is next to a gentlemanly club. Equator coffee is clean, and had a friendly staff.
author: adam t.

description: wow. cashew milk has officially surpassed all other milks in lattes. a milk is the make or break in a latte, and equator - you are rocking it!! I'm going back tomorrow. need this daily!!
author: Elise H.

description: Walked in for an after dinner drink before the Marina & the Diamonds show. I was greeted by an exceptionally friendly guy upon entering this delightful cafe. The staff were helpful, knowledgeable and most important sincere. I had quite a few questions about the drinks which they happily answered. I decided to order the Coconut White Russian. SO GOOD! Perfect ratio of espresso, liqueur & milk and it is garnished with some luscious & tasty thick coconut flakes. High quality drink, boosted my mood and I danced all night next door at the Waldorf.
author: Reyna R.

description: SO annoying.  Really great drinks, but the music is WAY too loud, the staff are throwing and dropping things.  One lady who was making drinks (13th January @ 3pm, black lady with tattoos on her chest) has the loudest voice ever and was totally obnoxious.  I left after half an hour.  Terrible.
author: James T.

description: Good coffee. Slow. Have to walk with open, full coffee some distance to get lids promoting spills. Cheap cups and lids.
author: adam b.

description: First time here and from out of town.  The staff was very friendly and accommodating.  I ordered a Soy Iced Chai Latte.  Loved it!
author: Eddie Z.
